text: okay great thank you for your patience
uh I'm Scott Lehman the mixed reality
lead for supreasteria and I'm here to
talk a little bit about the past present
and the future of mixed reality
so looking at the history of mixed
reality first uh mixed reality is this
spectrum between the real world the
physical world and the digital world so
on one side you've got virtuality where
you're immersed in a digital world and
largely cut off from The Real World and
that's great for things like training
and entertainment or not and then on the
other side you've got augmented reality
where you're focused on the real world
but your augmented reality adding
digital objects into the real world so
you can do that with your phone but you
can also do that with wearable AR
headsets like the whole lens too
and this is what the whole lens 2 is
built for it's meant to be a device that
you can wear
in the real world in work locations for
Enterprise use and see digital objects
Holograms in the real world and use your
hands your voice and your eyes to
control those objects and do training
and learn more about what's going on in
the real world
this is one use case we work with at
supreasteria as part of holocare and
this is where we take specific patient
data and visualize it as a 3D hologram
for surgical planning so multiple
surgeons can look at the same 3D
hologram of the patient's heart in this
case and look at the problem that they
need to solve and have a spatial
conversation together to say okay
perhaps there's a hole in this heart
that needs to be repaired how are we
going to approach that in the safest way
possible and have a conversation as if
that heart was really in the in the room
with them
so how did we get
to here it started in the 60s with uh
the sense sensorama which is kind of a
precursor to Virtual Reality this was a
one-person device where you'd stick your
your head in a box and you'd see a
stereo film of different experiences
like a motorcycle ride you'd also feel
the vibrations of the motorcycle and
smell the smells and feel wind in your
face this was an attempt to immerse
people beyond what was possible at that
time
and then also in the 60s you had the
sort of Damocles which was a ceiling
mounted virtual reality display it was
actually transparent the display so it
was a little bit augment reality and so
this allowed you to see wireframe forms
and it had head tracking so as you moved
your head around the room you'd see this
3D wireframe shape from different angles
and then in the 80s the technology
started to be commercialized for for
Enterprise companies like vpl and NASA
started using VR for training and then
in the 90s there was a push to try and
bring VR into consumers with VR arcades
and um some some failed VR consumer
products
and then in the the 2010s due to the
smartphones basically in the technology
around displays and tracking for
smartphones we had the Oculus Rift as a
Kickstarter and then soon after the
success of that a number of companies
started making commercial VR headsets
like the Oculus cv1 the HTC Vive
PlayStation VR and also in the 2010s we
had the Pokemon go from run on as well
as people started selling wearable AR
headsets like the whole lens one for
Enterprise use the magic leap 2 which
was one of the first consumer wearable
AR headsets It was a commercial failure
and the hololens too and also we started
to see Standalone VR headsets headsets
that didn't rely on an external computer
so right now the whole lens 2 is still
around it's still one of the leading
Enterprise wearable AR headsets but last
year uh gained some competition with the
MagiClip 2. this is a similar device a
wearable AR device with transparent
lenses this is a little bit different
form factor in that all the Computing
and the battery is on your belt instead
of being on your head so it's a
different form factor and it's got a
physical controller that you can
um you can hold as well instead of just
relying on on hand tracking
and this is a example demo application
um
that I'm running in my in my living room
and this is showing the effect of
wildfires around the world and how they
can be managed
so you can see the real world but you're
seeing this digital objects embedded in
the real world and you can interact with
them using that hand controller
and one of the more interesting things
about the magic loop 2 is it has this
functionality of global dimming so with
the transparent display you can
determine how much the real world you
want to see you can turn turn that from
zero to 100 and 100 it's almost blocking
out all the light so it's a VR like
experience at 100 so you can kind of
determine how much of a augmented
reality or virtuality like uh experience
you want
if you want to Paradise the robot or
prioritize the digital information
also coming out last year was the
metaquest pro this is a high-end
Standalone VR headset uh kind of a
successor to The Meta Quest 2 and one
interesting thing about this device is
that it has color stereo cam cameras on
the outside so you can see the real
world via those cameras in a technique
called pass through AR
so you're you're not seeing the real
world directly if I have our transparent
display but you're seeing it by these
cameras which you're showing on your
screens and so you can have this digital
content embedded in the real world in
the same fashion using this VR headset
in terms of development for mixed
reality your two main options or the two
most popular options are the unity or
unreal game engines
if you're working with the unity the
mixed reality toolkit which is supported
for whole lens and magically 2 as well
as some VR headsets can be a good a good
way to start it was developed by
Microsoft and they had a full-time team
originally there's recently been let go
so now it's been released into the
community so we'll have to see if that
keeps developing but also if you're
using Unity the XR interaction toolkit
and AR Foundation are great to get you
started as well
in terms of services for mixed reality
there's a number of companies that will
offer visual Positioning Systems
basically systems that allow you to
generate a 3D fingerprint of the world
and then anchor content to that position
in the world so Microsoft has got a
service called Azure spatial anchors
that does that and Microsoft also offers
Azure object anchors where you can
upload a 3D model of a real object and
then match against that and as you're
Mandarin where you can take a really
complex 3D model and stream a rendering
of that to the whole lens too so you
don't have to worry about the complexity
of the model
looking at the future of mixture healthy
in less than two weeks Apple has got the
worldwide developer conference on the
5th of June and there's a lot of rumors
that they'll be announcing a virtuality
device uh
for that event and it's interesting
because like the metaquest pro it's
rumored to have multiple cameras on the
outside so that you can do pass-through
AR so it'd be a high-end VR device it's
rumored to be around maybe three
thousand dollars that also allows you to
do augmented reality via that device and
it's rumored not to have a traditional
VR controller but to use hand tracking
and possibly a wearable hand controller
as well and that's interesting because
uh if it's successful it could be a lot
of people's first experiences uh with
wearable AR uh experiences for consumers
in the living room or in the office
and it's also interesting that Apple
seems to be not focusing on gaming so
much which has been a big focus of
virtuality for from matter and valve and
other companies so it could
begin to push virtuality and mixed
reality
beyond the script of gaming into a more
General spatial Computing use case
another interesting recent development
is uh Nerfs neural Radiance fields and
this is a machine learning process where
you you supply a number of images still
photos or videos and it's able to
generate a 3D scene
um from those images this is different
to photogrammetry which is where you
give a bunch of images and it creates a
3D model this isn't creating a 3D model
it's creating a simulation of what a
particular camera Viewpoint would see so
there's no 3D model there per se this is
a Nerf that one of my colleagues Delmer
on the mixed reality team made recently
so he recorded a video
we fed it into the uh the machine
learning algorithm and this is what it
generated a kind of drone flyby
um
of that scene and so this can be a very
interesting way to generate content for
VR and AR in the future
and talking more broadly uh mixed route
is dependent on all the technologies
that we use to understand the real world
so sensors and machine learning when you
use these devices and use your voice
you're using AI to understand what you
want we're using machine learning to
train the hand tracking algorithms that
allow you to reach out and interact with
Holograms using your hands
and more as more and more machine
learning develops that allows us to
understand the context of houses and
you're using this device what's going on
in the room what are the objects what
the space is like as well as what you
intend to do what you want the use cases
for mixed reality will develop one of
the rumors for the the Apple device is
that you might be able to use Siri in
order to generate through procedural
generation spaces or digital objects in
your space so you might be able to have
a conversation with the device to
redecorate your apartment for example
thank you I hope that's been an
interesting look at the the past and
potential future of mixed reality
